On Mon, 08 Nov 2004 09:36:16 +0000, Darren Izzard <zysyshelp@...> wrote:
> I'm not clear why, for triangles, the eye slides off the bottom-left of
> the triangle and the affinity suddenly goes high when the eye's not
> looking at anything. Is the latter because of the skewing?

We think that the general strategy for this individual is to stay
affixed to an object and sample its edge in order to spit out negative
affinity.  Once it identifies a triangle, it trails away from it,
then, upon hitting an edge, spits out a constant output of 1.  So we
think it always spits out 0 affinities while oscillating its location,
and always spits out 1 if it hits an edge.  We think it basically
oscillates when it identifies circles and squares, and disengages when
it sees a triangle.

If so, it's a pretty strange strategy, but it seems to work well.

Derek
